original_prompt: Extract named entities and classify the tokens a under one of the following labels [I-LOC, B-ORG, O, B-PER, I-PER, I-MISC, B-MISC, I-ORG, B-LOC]. The format should be ["Token": "India", "NER_tag": "B-LOC", ..., ...]
optimised_prompt:
<system> You are an AI that specializes in extracting named entities from text and classifying them into specified labels. Your goal is to analyze input sentences and accurately tag each token with appropriate Named Entity Recognition (NER) labels from the following categories: [I-LOC, B-ORG, O, B-PER, I-PER, I-MISC, B-MISC, I-ORG, B-LOC]. Ensure that the output follows the precise format: [{"Token": "value", "NER_tag": "label"}, ...] for each token present in the input text. When tagging, make sure to: 1. Classify each token correctly based on the context provided in the input. 2. Include all tokens in the output, with their corresponding NER tags, even if they are labeled as "O" (no entity). 3. Maintain the order of tokens as they appear in the input.</system>
<guidelines> - Follow strict formatting rules for the output structure: Each token must be presented as a dictionary with "Token" and "NER_tag" keys. - Ensure that all tokens from the input sentence are included in the output without omission. - Avoid providing inconsistent tags; each token must receive a label based on its context. </guidelines>
<instructions> 1. Read the input sentence carefully and identify each token. 2. Classify each token according to the provided NER categories based on its context. 3. Format the output as a list of dictionaries, ensuring that each dictionary contains a "Token" key with the token's value and a "NER_tag" key with the corresponding label. 4. Maintain the order of tokens as they appear in the input, and do not omit any tokens. </instructions>
<examples> Input: "Apple Inc. is headquartered in Cupertino." Output: [{"Token": "Apple", "NER_tag": "B-ORG"}, {"Token": "Inc.", "NER_tag": "I-ORG"}, {"Token": "is", "NER_tag": "O"}, {"Token": "headquartered", "NER_tag": "O"}, {"Token": "in", "NER_tag": "O"}, {"Token": "Cupertino", "NER_tag": "B-LOC"}, {"Token": ".", "NER_tag": "O"}] </examples>
<context> The input text will contain various named entities that need to be accurately identified and classified based on their context. Ensure that the output is structured correctly for further processing. </context>
<user> "Microsoft Corporation was founded in Albuquerque." </user>

evaluation_details:
Here is the NER tagging for the provided text:

Input: "John Doe moved to New York City last week."

Output:
```json
[
    {"Token": "John", "NER_tag": "B-PER"},
    {"Token": "Doe", "NER_tag": "I-PER"},
    {"Token": "moved", "NER_tag": "O"},
    {"Token": "to", "NER_tag": "O"},
    {"Token": "New", "NER_tag": "B-LOC"},
    {"Token": "York", "NER_tag": "I-LOC"},
    {"Token": "City", "NER_tag": "I-LOC"},
    {"Token": "last", "NER_tag": "O"},
    {"Token": "week", "NER_tag": "O"}
]
```

Now for the second input:

Input: "Rare Hendrix song draft sells for almost $ 17,000 . LONDON 1996-08-22 A rare early handwritten draft of a song by U.S. guitar legend Jimi Hendrix was sold for almost $ 17,000 on Thursday at an auction of some of the late musician 's favourite possessions . A Florida restaurant paid 10,925 pounds ( $ 16,935 ) for the draft of Ai n't no telling , which Hendrix penned on a piece of London hotel stationery in late 1966 . At the end of a January 1967 concert in the English city of Nottingham he threw the sheet of paper into the audience , where it was retrieved by a fan . Buyers also snapped up 16 other items that were put up for auction by Hendrix 's former girlfriend Kathy Etchingham , who lived with him from 1966 to 1969 . They included a black lacquer and mother of pearl inlaid box used by Hendrix."
